Is religion the expression of subordinate thinking?

post_info.post_title: Is religion the expression of subordinate thinking?

Is religion the expression of subordinate thinking?

 The unexamined assumption here seems to be that people who have a religious faith either can't or won't think for themselves. Their (religious) thoughts are "subordinate" in the sense that they obey instructions about what to think which are given by priests, pastors, etc. 
 
 I suspect there is a further hidden assumption that, let's say Christians, have been brainwashed otherwise they would reach the same conclusions as atheists do about the nature of religious experience. 
 
 If my guesswork is accurate, you need to provide some reasoning that supports the conclusions you wish to be inferred from your assumptions. 
 
 On the subject of thought in general, at any given time and place how many independent thinkers are in circulation? We are (mostly) transmitters of ideas borrowed from earlier minds. Very few original ideas are to be found at any time. In that sense second-hand or subordinate thinking about almost everything is virtually the norm.
 
 James.

 Ok let's say that what I mean is, are religious people inclined to seek the structure of a system in which they are subordinate?
 
 Do they need to be subordinate in some way?
People are subordinate in some way in virtually any system, it appears to me unreasonable to accuse religious people in particular of having this inclination.

Ok let's say that what I mean is, are religious people inclined to seek the structure of a system in which they are subordinate?
 
 Do they need to be subordinate in some way?

 
 You've just moved the field of inquiry from a question about subordinate thinking to a vague question about "structures".
 
 If by "structure" you mean the organization of a society or other group and the relations between its members which determines its working, then subordinate ranks are likely to be a necessary condition of its efficiency. In other words, a social hierarchy presupposes subordinate rank and the question of "need" isn't relevant.
 
 It only makes sense to say that people feel a "need" to be subordinate within a religious (or any other) organisation if we assume that they have developed a psychological dependency on the authority of others who are "senior" to them. 
 
 (This elaborates a bit on what Symbiote has just said).
 
 James.

Unfortunately, Muslims are also obliged to submit to the haranguing of the imams as well.
 
 And, as for Christians, according to Nietzsche:
 
 
Nietzsche called this one correctly. Christianity, which purports to be the religion of love, is only sporadically anything of the kind. It is primarily a religion of slavery and submission. Christian individualism, when it exists at all, is legitimized only by obedience to God. In a Christian worldview there is always someone to be obeyed, whether visible cleric or invisible Nobodaddy. You must submit; the only argument is about to whom your obedience is owed, and what humans under what circumstances may transmit the orders of God. Without that sinew of obedience the entire world-view disintegrates.

 
 http://esr.ibiblio.org/?p=10

Nietzsche wasn't claiming that religiosity was the expression of subordinate thinking, rather that christian culture, jewish culture, western culture in general, even among the non-religious, was a slave morality, it admires things because of what they are not, rather than what they are.

Subordination is a fact of life it is found throughout civilization and it stems from the family unit..... Catholicism is merely a large family.
 
 I have chosen to be subordinate and to accept my role in the Catholic Family. It was not forced upon me, I was not brainwashed into accepting it... I wanted to accept it. 
 
 The teachings of Christ is subordination to each other, of servitude to God, to christians and to mankind. 
 
 Jesus said "the truth shall set you free"
 
 But free from what?.... free from being subordinate from the truth...no!
 
 The freedom Christ is talking about is freedom from deception....especially self deception grounded in self servitude and this freedom can only be found in subordination to him
 
 Abortion is a good one to take for example.
 
 1. The deception/self deception
 
 Abortion is safe, its my body, A fetus is part of a womans body, Its nothimg more than a blob of tissue, A fetus is not a person, a fetus is not a human being, A fetus is not an individual.
 
 2. The Truth
 
 A fetus is a individual human being and therefore a person (in that sense) which is a lot more than a blob of tissue and genetically it is clear that the fetus is not part of a womans body, not part of your body, Abortion is clearly unsafe for the fetus since abortion kills him or her.
 
 3. Gods truth.
 
 all members of the human race are made in the image and likeness of God and deserving of respect and protection from those who seek them harm...the truth is a pregnant woman should not seek to harm her child.
 
 To know god is to know the truth (in this case about the nature of human being) even if god has not explicitly said in the bible not to procure abortion, but to know him is to know the truth (even if your parents had not told you not to take drugs, you would know if they would or would not approve because you know them on a deeper level than mere words) and to know the truth sets you free from the deceptions others try to decieve you with and also sets you free from your own self deceptions driven on by fear, by desire ect.
 
 we are all subordinate to someone or something even if we ourselves do not realise that we are subordinate to them. Faith is often a realisation and rebellion against subordination to certain factions and deceptions, media, culture, governments..but it also calls you to rebell against your own desires and self deceptions, you realise these are men and women simply persuing their own self interests then you realise it is only by self sacrafice that you can be an example to them, it is then you realise the power of the cross.
